misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Implemented pass/fail instead of full A–F letter-grade mapping
misconceptions.description: The student reads a numeric grade but only classifies it as "passing" or "F" instead of mapping it to the required letter grades A, B, C, D, or F based on numeric ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the task is to determine whether a grade is passing (>=70) or failing, and to print "passing" or "F" accordingly, rather than outputting specific letter grades.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must map the numeric grade to one of the letter grades A, B, C, D, or F according to the specified numeric ranges (A: 90–100, B: 80–89, C: 70–79, D: 60–69, F: below 60) and print the corresponding letter, not just "passing".
symptoms: Program never prints the letters A, B, C, or D.
For grades 70 and above, the output is the word "passing" rather than a letter grade.
There are no conditional branches distinguishing the A, B, C, and D ranges from each other.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely misreading or oversimplifying the problem specification and/or not recognizing that multi-way selection (else-if chain) is needed to distinguish multiple disjoint ranges.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and list the required ranges (A, B, C, D, F). Then implement an if–else-if ladder that checks each range and prints the correct letter, for example checking from highest range (A) down to lowest (F).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The only outputs related to grades are "passing" and "F", and there are no conditions or print statements for A, B, C, or D, which clearly contradicts the problem specification.

evidence.note: The only grade outputs are "passing" and "F"; there are no branches or print statements for letter grades A, B, C, or D.

misconceptions.name: Misunderstanding of nested if-else structure and dangling else
misconceptions.description: The student uses nested if statements without braces such that the else is bound to the inner if (grade >= 70) instead of the outer if (grade >= 60). As a result, grades below 60 produce no output instead of printing "F".
misconceptions.student_belief: The student likely believes that the else clause is paired with the outer condition (grade >= 60), intending logic like "if grade >= 60 then passing else F".
misconceptions.correct_understanding:
In Java, an else is always associated with the nearest unmatched if. Without braces, the code
if (grade >= 60)
    if (grade >= 70)
        ...
else
    ...
parses so that the else pairs with the inner if (grade >= 70). To make else belong to the outer if, braces or an else-if structure must be used. Also, all grades below 60 must explicitly be handled as F.
symptoms: For a grade less than 60 (e.g., 50), the program prints nothing instead of the required letter grade F.
For grades between 60 and 69, the program prints "F", treating them as failing, which also conflicts with the intended D range in the spec.
For grades 70 and above, the program prints "passing" instead of a specific letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion about how else associates with if in nested conditionals (dangling else problem) and lack of braces to make the intended structure explicit.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review how Java matches each else to the nearest previous if without an else. Use braces to group statements, and rewrite the logic as a clear if–else-if ladder that covers all ranges, including an explicit final else for F (<60). Test with values like 50, 65, 75, 85, and 95 to see which branch executes.
related_concepts: Exhaustive case coverage in condition ranges
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The structure uses nested if without braces in the classic dangling-else pattern, and the resulting behavior clearly leaves grades below 60 with no output, indicating a misunderstanding of if–else binding.

evidence.note: Because else binds to the nearest if, this is equivalent to nested ifs where the else matches (grade >= 70), leaving grades below 60 with no output instead of printing F.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for C and D
misconceptions.name: Dangling Else in Nested If Structure
misconceptions.description: The student implemented nested 'if' statements without using explicit curly braces, causing the 'else' clause to bind to the inner 'if' statement instead of the outer one, leading to incorrect conditional grouping and unpredictable logic flow.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that indentation or the chaining of nested 'if' statements without braces will cause the 'else' at the end to automatically associate with the outermost 'if' statement.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Without curly braces, an 'else' always binds to the nearest preceding *unmatched* 'if'. In this structure, the 'else' handles the case where `(grade >= 60)` is true but `(grade >= 70)` is false (i.e., grades 60-69). This leaves the case `grade < 60` (F grades) completely unhandled, and the logic is broken for all cases.
symptoms: Grades below 60 produce no output.
Grades 60-69 produce an incorrect output ('F').
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of Java's parsing rules for control structures when curly braces are omitted, specifically the dangling else problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Always use curly braces to explicitly define the block of code controlled by an 'if' or 'else' statement, especially when nesting conditions or when the body contains more than one line (even though Java allows omitting braces for a single line).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The structure of lines 15-19 perfectly exemplifies the dangling else binding problem.

evidence.note: The 'else' on line 18 binds to the inner 'if' on line 16, due to missing curly braces around the inner block, breaking the logical intent.

misconceptions.correct_understanding: The solution must use distinct conditional branches (ideally `if-else if-else`) to check specific ranges (e.g., >= 90 for A, >= 80 for B, etc.) and output the exact letter grade required by the prompt.
symptoms: Only two possible outputs are defined, 'passing' and 'F'.
Required grade categories (A, B, C, D) are missing.

misconceptions.remediation_hint: Outline all required grade ranges (90-100, 80-89, etc.) before coding, and ensure your control flow structure (`if-else if-else`) handles every possible input range sequentially.

evidence.note: Only checks for grade >= 70 and prints 'passing' instead of correctly segmenting into A, B, and C.
The only explicit failing grade output is 'F', which due to the logic error, is only triggered for grades 60-69.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for C and D
misconceptions.name: Incomplete nested if-else for multi-range classification
misconceptions.description: Student uses nested if-else with only two condition levels (>= 60, >= 70) to classify five distinct grade ranges. This creates a logic gap where grades 60-69 have no handler, and produces no output for those inputs. The student does not understand that nested if-else can only branch into two paths per level, insufficient for five ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: Checking grade >= 60, then within that checking grade >= 70, will properly categorize all five letter grade ranges (A, B, C, D, F).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To handle five distinct ranges, use either: (a) independent if-else statements for each range with explicit boolean conditions (grade >= 90, grade >= 80 && grade < 90, etc.), or (b) properly structured nested if-else with else clauses for every branch. The current nested structure only provides two execution paths, leaving the 60-69 range unhandled.
symptoms: Grades 60-69 produce no output
Grades 70+ all print 'passing' instead of individual letter grades
Only 3 of 5 grade ranges are handled (F, generic 70+, and nothing for 60-69)
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of nested if-else control flow. Student appears to think checking two conditions sequentially will cover all cases, but does not account for the gap in 60-69 range or recognize that both 70+ grades get the same generic output.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Use an if-else chain with explicit range checks: if (grade >= 90) ... else if (grade >= 80) ... else if (grade >= 70) ... else if (grade >= 60) ... else ... This ensures each range gets exactly one handler.
related_concepts: Edge case testing (test grades at boundaries: 59, 60, 69, 70, 79, 80, 89, 90, 100)
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence because the code structure clearly shows incomplete nested logic with a missing else clause for the inner if, combined with silent failure for grades 60-69. The pattern is unambiguous.

evidence.note: The inner if has no else clause. When grade is 60-69, outer if is true but inner if is false, so nothing executes (silent failure). When grade is 70+, 'passing' prints regardless of whether it's 70-79, 80-89, or 90-100.

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Incorrect output: generic 'passing' instead of specific letter grades
misconceptions.description: Student outputs the string 'passing' for grades >= 70, instead of the required specific letter grades A, B, C, D, or F. Additionally, the output format does not match the specification (should be 'Letter grade: X').
misconceptions.student_belief: Printing 'passing' for grades >= 70 satisfies the output requirement for a grade calculator.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The problem requires mapping each numeric grade to its specific letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) and outputting in the format 'Letter grade: X'. A grade of 85 must output 'Letter grade: B', not 'passing'.
symptoms: Output is 'passing' instead of letter grades
Output format does not include 'Letter grade:' prefix
No distinction between B (80-89), A (90-100), or C (70-79)—all treated identically
misconceptions.root_cause: Student implemented only a binary check (pass/fail at 60) without mapping individual grades to letters. Combined with the incomplete nested logic, student did not implement the full five-way classification required.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: For each grade range, output the correct letter: if (grade >= 90) System.out.println("Letter grade: A"); else if (grade >= 80) System.out.println("Letter grade: B"); ... and so on.
related_concepts: Requirements analysis: reading and understanding problem constraints
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly prints 'passing' and the expected output format is clearly specified in the problem statement. The mismatch is unambiguous.

evidence.note: Output is hardcoded as 'passing' for all grades >= 70. Should instead be 'Letter grade: A', 'Letter grade: B', 'Letter grade: C', or 'Letter grade: D' depending on the specific range.
Output for F is correct letter, but missing the 'Letter grade: ' prefix as shown in the problem specification (expected: 'Letter grade: F').

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: No explicit conditions for letter grades A and B
misconceptions.description: Student does not implement distinct boolean conditions to check for grades A (90-100) and B (80-89). The code only checks >= 70 generically, without subdividing into the specific ranges needed for A, B, and C.
misconceptions.student_belief: Checking grade >= 70 is sufficient to identify all grades B and above.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Grades must be classified into five specific ranges: A requires grade >= 90, B requires 80 <= grade < 90, C requires 70 <= grade < 80, D requires 60 <= grade < 70, F requires grade < 60. Without explicit upper-bound checks, ranges A, B, and C cannot be distinguished.
symptoms: No conditions check for grade >= 90 (A range)
No conditions check for grade >= 80 (B range)
Generic check for grade >= 70 treats B, C as one category
misconceptions.root_cause: Student's approach conflates multiple ranges under a single condition. Likely misunderstood that five distinct ranges require five distinct conditions (not three nested conditions).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add explicit if-else branches checking each range: if (grade >= 90) { letter = 'A'; } else if (grade >= 80) { letter = 'B'; } else if (grade >= 70) { letter = 'C'; } etc.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code visibly lacks conditions for grades >= 90 and >= 80. Only >= 70 and >= 60 are checked, making it impossible to identify A or B grades individually.

evidence.note: Only two nested conditions: >= 60 and >= 70. Missing explicit checks for >= 90 (A) and >= 80 (B). This makes it impossible to distinguish between grades 70-100.

misconceptions.name: Misunderstanding of nested if-else association (dangling else)
misconceptions.description: The student uses nested if statements without braces, expecting the else to pair with the outer condition `if (grade >= 60)`. In Java, the else actually pairs with the nearest unmatched inner `if (grade >= 70)`, so grades 60–69 are classified as F and grades below 60 produce no output at all.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that the `else` corresponds to the outer `if (grade >= 60)` and will run whenever the grade is below 60.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, an `else` always pairs with the closest preceding unmatched `if` within the same block, regardless of indentation. To have an `else` (or `else if`) correspond to an outer condition, you need to use braces and/or a proper `if/else if/else` chain.
symptoms: For grades >= 70, the program prints `passing` instead of a letter grade.
For grades between 60 and 69, the program prints `F` even though these should be D (60–69).
For grades below 60, the program prints nothing at all instead of `F`.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion about how Java associates `else` with `if` when braces are omitted, possibly trusting indentation rather than language rules.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add braces and rewrite this as a clear `if/else if/else` chain. For example: `if (grade >= 90) { ... } else if (grade >= 80) { ... } ... else { System.out.println("F"); }`. This will make it obvious which `else` goes with which `if`.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The nested `if` without braces exactly matches the classic dangling-else pattern, and the resulting behavior clearly contradicts the intended F-range handling.

evidence.note: Because there are no braces, the `else` is bound to `if (grade >= 70)`, not to `if (grade >= 60)`, leading to incorrect handling of 60–69 and <60.

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Implementing pass/fail check instead of full letter-grade mapping
misconceptions.description: Instead of mapping numeric grades to letter grades A, B, C, D, and F over the specified ranges, the student only checks two thresholds (60 and 70) and prints `passing` or `F`. There is no logic for A/B/C/D letter outputs, and some numeric ranges are not handled correctly or at all.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that distinguishing between `passing` (>=70) and `F` is sufficient, or that outputting a generic `passing` message satisfies the requirement to print a letter grade.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must categorize every possible numeric grade (0–100) into one of five letter grades: A (90–100), B (80–89), C (70–79), D (60–69), and F (below 60). Each range should be checked with appropriate conditional logic, and the program should print the correct letter (A/B/C/D/F), not just `passing`.
symptoms: No cases where the program prints `A`, `B`, `C`, or `D`.
All grades >= 70 produce the same output `passing`, losing the distinction between A, B, and C.
Grades between 60 and 69 are printed as `F` due to the incorrect else association, and grades below 60 produce no output instead of `F`.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student did not implement the specified multi-range letter-grade algorithm, instead coding a simplified pass/fail check and omitting separate branches for A, B, C, and D.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the current conditional with a full `if/else if/else` chain that checks ranges in descending order: `if (grade >= 90) { System.out.println("Letter grade: A"); } else if (grade >= 80) { ... } else if (grade >= 70) { ... } else if (grade >= 60) { ... } else { System.out.println("Letter grade: F"); }`.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is no code at all for A/B/C/D outputs, and the only messages are `passing` and `F`, which clearly contradict the problem statement that demands A–F letter grades.

evidence.note: This code only distinguishes `passing` versus `F` and never outputs any letter grades (A, B, C, D) as required by the specification.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for C and D
misconceptions.name: Dangling Else Pairing Error
misconceptions.description: The student has used nested if statements without mandatory curly braces, leading to the `else` clause pairing unintentionally with the nearest preceding `if` statement (the inner one, `if (grade >= 70)` in C/C++/Java context), which is not their likely intent. In Java, however, the `else` strictly binds to the nearest *unmatched* `if`. When written as the student did, the `else` intended for the inner conditional `if (grade >= 70)` is actually forced to match the nearest unmatched `if`, which is the outer one, `if (grade >= 60)`. This structure is problematic and fails to implement the required grading logic.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that the structure provided implements a sequence of mutually exclusive grade checks, likely intending the final `else` (line 18) to catch grades below 60, and assuming the inner logic handles passing grades.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java without curly braces, an `else` statement is always paired with the nearest preceding unmatched `if`. While the student's indentation suggests the `else` is paired with the outer `if` (which is technically correct for the `if/if/else` structure as written), the entire nested structure lacks the complex logic needed to differentiate A, B, C, and D grades, and is heavily reliant on indentation that the compiler ignores. Proper nested conditionals or `if-else if-else` chaining requires careful use of braces {} or explicit structuring to ensure intended flow control.
symptoms: Incorrect classification of grades
Only outputs 'passing' or 'F'
Only one `else` block is used to cover all low grades
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of how non-braced nested `if` and `else` statements associate in Java, or simply an incomplete implementation of the required conditional logic.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Use curly braces `{}` to clearly define the blocks associated with each `if` and `else`. Implement the full `if-else if` chain (A, B, C, D) before including a final `else` for F.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code uses a minimal, incomplete nested IF structure where the required logic demands a full IF-ELSE IF chain for 5 distinct outputs (A, B, C, D, F). The current structure can only differentiate three outcomes (F, passing 60-69, passing 70+) and only provides two actual string outputs ('passing' or 'F').

evidence.note: The incomplete conditional logic (only checking two thresholds) fails to implement the A, B, C, D structure. Furthermore, the conditional statements only output 'passing' or 'F', failing the mapping requirement.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Improper conditional structure for multiple mutually exclusive ranges
misconceptions.description: Student uses nested if statements instead of if-else-if chaining to evaluate mutually exclusive grade ranges. This results in incomplete condition checking and inability to properly distinguish between different grade brackets (A, B, C, D, F).
misconceptions.student_belief: Nested if statements are sufficient to check different conditions sequentially; checking grade >= 60 and then grade >= 70 is enough to categorize all grades
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For mutually exclusive ranges, use if-else-if chaining so only one branch executes. Each condition should check its specific range. For example: if (grade >= 90) {...} else if (grade >= 80) {...} else if (grade >= 70) {...} etc.
symptoms: Grades between 60-69 produce no output
Only two conditions checked instead of five ranges
Missing outputs for letter grades A, B, C, D
misconceptions.root_cause: Incomplete understanding of how to structure conditionals for multiple mutually exclusive cases; mistaken belief that nested ifs suffice for range checking
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Refactor using if-else-if chaining. Start with the highest range: if (grade >= 90) print A; else if (grade >= 80) print B; else if (grade >= 70) print C; else if (grade >= 60) print D; else print F
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code clearly shows incomplete if-else structure with missing branches. The student only implements two nested conditions instead of five required ranges. This pattern is unambiguous.

evidence.note: Only two nested conditions check grades. Missing explicit checks for A (90-100), B (80-89), C (70-79), D (60-69). No distinction between overlapping ranges.

misconceptions.name: Dangling else / misunderstanding of else binding
misconceptions.description: The else statement is intended to handle all non-passing grades, but due to improper nesting, it binds to the inner if (grade >= 70) instead of the outer if (grade >= 60). This creates incorrect behavior where grades 60-69 produce no output instead of failing the inner condition gracefully.
misconceptions.student_belief: The else applies to the outer if statement (grade >= 60), so it should catch all grades below 60
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, an else statement always binds to the nearest preceding if. Without explicit braces, the else in this code belongs to if (grade >= 70), not the outer if (grade >= 60). To avoid ambiguity and ensure correct logic, always use braces: if (...) { ... } else { ... }
symptoms: Grades 60-69 produce no output (logical gap)
Only grades >= 70 and grades < 60 produce output
The F grade is printed only for grades < 60, not for 60-69 range
misconceptions.root_cause: Lack of understanding of Java's else-binding rules; poor use of braces and indentation to clarify intent; may have learned syntax without understanding that else binds to the nearest if
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Always use braces around if-else blocks for clarity: if (condition) { ... } else { ... }. This eliminates ambiguity. If using if-else-if chains, ensure braces are consistent: if (...) { ... } else if (...) { ... } else { ... }
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code structure unambiguously shows the else bound to the inner if. Tracing through the logic reveals that grades 60-69 have no path to output. The dangling else problem is a well-known Java gotcha and this code exhibits all its hallmarks.

evidence.note: The else on line 25 binds to the inner if (grade >= 70), not the outer if (grade >= 60). Grades 60-69 satisfy the outer condition but fail the inner condition, so they fall through with no else clause, producing no output.
